items.title: Trump is all smiles with Zelenskyy but shifts goalposts for Ukraine peace deal
items.standfirst: Ukraine’s president received a warmer Oval Office welcome than last time but Trump rules out need for ceasefireDonald Trump has welcomed Ukraine’s Volodymyr Zelenskyy to the White House but appeared to rule out arranging a ceasefire as part of plans to try to end the country’s war with Russia.The US president’s meeting with Zelenskyy on Monday went more smoothly than their first encounter in the Oval Office six months ago, when the Ukrainian leader was ambushed and berated by Trump and Vice-President JD Vance. Continue reading...
items.content: Ukraine’s president received a warmer Oval Office welcome than last time but Trump rules out need for ceasefireDonald Trump has welcomed Ukraine’s Volodymyr Zelenskyy to the White House but appeared to rule out arranging a ceasefire as part of plans to try to end the country’s war with Russia.The US president’s meeting with Zelenskyy on Monday went more smoothly than their first encounter in the Oval Office six months ago, when the Ukrainian leader was ambushed and berated by Trump and Vice-President JD Vance. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump says he'll call Putin after meeting with Zelenskyy
items.standfirst: President Trump said Monday that he would call Russian President Vladimir Putin following his White House meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. CBS News senior national security correspondent Charlie D'Agata has more.
items.content: President Trump said Monday that he would call Russian President Vladimir Putin following his White House meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy. CBS News senior national security correspondent Charlie D'Agata has more.

items.title: Trump says lawyers are drafting executive order to end mail-in voting
items.standfirst: Announcement comes days after Putin allegedly told Trump US elections were rigged because of postal ballotsUS politics live – latest updatesDonald Trump on Monday announced that lawyers are drafting an executive order to eliminate mail-in voting, days after Vladimir Putin told him US elections were rigged because of postal ballots.In a White House meeting alongside Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy, Trump said: “We’re going to start with an executive order that’s being written right now by the best lawyers in the country to end mail in ballots because they’re corrupt.” Continue reading...
items.content: Announcement comes days after Putin allegedly told Trump US elections were rigged because of postal ballotsUS politics live – latest updatesDonald Trump on Monday announced that lawyers are drafting an executive order to eliminate mail-in voting, days after Vladimir Putin told him US elections were rigged because of postal ballots.In a White House meeting alongside Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy, Trump said: “We’re going to start with an executive order that’s being written right now by the best lawyers in the country to end mail in ballots because they’re corrupt.” Continue reading...

items.title: Zelenskyy accuses Russia of ‘cynical’ attacks before Washington talks
items.standfirst: Ukrainian president says latest strikes have killed at least 10 people and intended to ‘humiliate diplomatic efforts’Russia-Ukraine war – latest news updatesVolodymyr Zelenskyy has accused Russia of trying to humiliate Ukraine and Europe by “deliberately killing civilians” before talks with Donald Trump in the White House to be attended by Ukraine’s president and a group of European leaders.Zelenskyy described the latest strikes by Moscow on four Ukrainian cities as “demonstrative and cynical”. At least seven people were killed in a drone attack on Kharkiv, including a small girl, while three were killed in another bombing in Zaporizhzhia, he said. Continue reading...
items.content: Ukrainian president says latest strikes have killed at least 10 people and intended to ‘humiliate diplomatic efforts’Russia-Ukraine war – latest news updatesVolodymyr Zelenskyy has accused Russia of trying to humiliate Ukraine and Europe by “deliberately killing civilians” before talks with Donald Trump in the White House to be attended by Ukraine’s president and a group of European leaders.Zelenskyy described the latest strikes by Moscow on four Ukrainian cities as “demonstrative and cynical”. At least seven people were killed in a drone attack on Kharkiv, including a small girl, while three were killed in another bombing in Zaporizhzhia, he said. Continue reading...

items.title: Zelensky urges Trump to bring 'peace through strength' against Russia
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Monday urged Donald Trump to exert "peace through strength" against Russia, echoing the US leader's own language ahead of a high-stakes White House meeting. "Russia can only be forced into peace through strength, and President Trump has that strength. We have to do everything right to make peace happen," Zelensky wrote on X. Analysis by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Emmanuelle Chaze.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Monday urged Donald Trump to exert "peace through strength" against Russia, echoing the US leader's own language ahead of a high-stakes White House meeting. "Russia can only be forced into peace through strength, and President Trump has that strength. We have to do everything right to make peace happen," Zelensky wrote on X. Analysis by FRANCE 24 correspondent in Kyiv, Emmanuelle Chaze.

items.title: Zelenskyy’s European ‘bodyguards’: which leaders will join Trump talks in Washington?
items.standfirst: Presidents, PMs and heads of Nato and European Commission to accompany Ukraine’s leader at White HouseRussia-Ukraine war – latest news updatesEuropean leaders arrive in Washington on Monday before Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s meeting with Donald Trump in the Oval Office, in a show of support for the Ukrainian president. It comes amid expectations that Trump will try to bully Zelenskyy into accepting a pro-Russia “peace plan” that would include Kyiv handing territory to Moscow. The Europeans have been described as Zelenskyy’s “bodyguards”, with memories fresh of the mauling he received in February during his last Oval Office visit. So, who are they? Continue reading...
items.content: Presidents, PMs and heads of Nato and European Commission to accompany Ukraine’s leader at White HouseRussia-Ukraine war – latest news updatesEuropean leaders arrive in Washington on Monday before Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s meeting with Donald Trump in the Oval Office, in a show of support for the Ukrainian president. It comes amid expectations that Trump will try to bully Zelenskyy into accepting a pro-Russia “peace plan” that would include Kyiv handing territory to Moscow. The Europeans have been described as Zelenskyy’s “bodyguards”, with memories fresh of the mauling he received in February during his last Oval Office visit. So, who are they? Continue reading...

items.title: Zelensky in Washington to discuss acceptable terms for peace deal

Details by FRANCE 24 correspondents in Ukraine and Brussels, Emmanuelle Chaze and Dave Keating.

items.title: Putin's demands would be bitter blow to Ukraine and could even lead to Zelenskyy's removal | Michael Clarke analysis
items.standfirst: Russian President Vladimir Putin reportedly demands that he be given control of the whole of the Donbas as part - and only part - of his price for any peace deal with Ukraine.
items.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin reportedly demands that he be given control of the whole of the Donbas as part - and only part - of his price for any peace deal with Ukraine.

items.title: Who will be at Zelensky's side for decisive talks with Trump on Ukraine-Russia war?
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said it was up to Russia to end its invasion, ahead of high-stakes talks on Monday with US counterpart Donald Trump, who is pressuring Ukraine to give up Crimea and abandon its NATO ambitions. The comments came hours before Zelensky and European leaders were scheduled to meet Trump in Washington, a follow-up to a summit between Trump and Putin in Alaska on Friday that failed to produce a ceasefire. Story by Morgan Ayre and Charlotte Lam.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said it was up to Russia to end its invasion, ahead of high-stakes talks on Monday with US counterpart Donald Trump, who is pressuring Ukraine to give up Crimea and abandon its NATO ambitions. The comments came hours before Zelensky and European leaders were scheduled to meet Trump in Washington, a follow-up to a summit between Trump and Putin in Alaska on Friday that failed to produce a ceasefire. Story by Morgan Ayre and Charlotte Lam.

items.content: Ukraine and its allies were scrambling Sunday to respond to President Donald Trump's apparent shift toward Vladimir Putin's hardline position after their summit in Alaska.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Trump met with Zelenskyy at the White House for discussions on Ukraine.
• Trump stated he would call Putin after the meeting with Zelenskyy.
• Trump announced an executive order to end mail-in voting.
• Lawyers are drafting the executive order to eliminate mail-in ballots.
• The meeting with Zelenskyy was more amicable than their previous encounter.

items.title: Newsmax to pay $67M to settle Dominion Voting Systems defamation case
items.standfirst: Newsmax will pay $67 million to settle a lawsuit accusing it of defaming the voting equipment company Dominion Voting Systems over its role in the 2020 election.
items.content: Newsmax will pay $67 million to settle a lawsuit accusing it of defaming the voting equipment company Dominion Voting Systems over its role in the 2020 election.

items.title: Newsmax Settles Dominion’s Defamation Lawsuit for $67 Million
Right-wing US network Newsmax to pay $67m over false 2020 election claims
items.standfirst: Newsmax has paid $27m so far, and will pay $20m in 2026 and $20m in 2027 to technology firm Dominion Voting Systems.
items.content: Newsmax has paid $27m so far, and will pay $20m in 2026 and $20m in 2027 to technology firm Dominion Voting Systems.

items.title: Newsmax to pay $67M in defamation case over false 2020 election claims
items.standfirst: The conservative network Newsmax has agreed to pay $67 million to settle a lawsuit accusing it of defaming a voting equipment company by spreading lies about President Donald Trump’s 2020 election loss.
items.content: The conservative network Newsmax has agreed to pay $67 million to settle a lawsuit accusing it of defaming a voting equipment company by spreading lies about President Donald Trump’s 2020 election loss.

items.title: Newsmax and Dominion settle for $67m in defamation suit over US election lies

items.content: Settlement came as case was headed to trial for jury to consider if conservative outlet was liable for damages US politics live – latest updates The conservative outlet Newsmax has agreed to pay $67m to Dominion Voting Systems to settle a defamation lawsuit over lies about voting in the 2020…

items.title: Newsmax to pay $67 million to settle Dominion Voting Systems’ defamation lawsuit
items.standfirst: A voter casts their ballot with a Dominion Voting Systems ImageCast Precinct optical scan tabulator at a polling station inside Rye City Hall in Rye, New York, US, on Tuesday, June 25, 2024.
items.content: A voter casts their ballot with a Dominion Voting Systems ImageCast Precinct optical scan tabulator at a polling station inside Rye City Hall in Rye, New York, US, on Tuesday, June 25, 2024.

items.title: Newsmax pays $67 million to settle defamation case linked to 2020 election coverage
items.standfirst: The right-wing news channel Newsmax has agreed to pay $67 million to Dominion Voting Systems over its coverage of the 2020 presidential election. A trial had been scheduled for October.
items.content: The right-wing news channel Newsmax has agreed to pay $67 million to Dominion Voting Systems over its coverage of the 2020 presidential election. A trial had been scheduled for October. (Image credit: Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images)

clusters.ai_summary:
• Newsmax will pay $67 million to settle a defamation lawsuit.
• The lawsuit accused Newsmax of defaming Dominion Voting Systems.
• Newsmax spread lies about the 2020 election loss.
• The settlement came as the case was headed to trial.
• Newsmax has paid $27 million so far, with further payments in 2026 and 2027.

clusters.title: Hamas agrees to latest Gaza ceasefire proposal, source in group says

bullet_summary: The plan reportedly involves a 60-day ceasefire "during which 10 Israeli hostages would be released alive, along with a number of bodies", said a source from Islamic Jihad
Reported by BBC World, Sky News World, France24 and others

items.title: Hamas agrees to latest Gaza ceasefire proposal, source in group says
items.standfirst: The proposal from regional mediators would see Israeli hostages released in two batches during a 60-day truce, according to a Palestinian official.
items.content: The proposal from regional mediators would see Israeli hostages released in two batches during a 60-day truce, according to a Palestinian official.

items.title: Hamas 'agrees to ceasefire-hostage deal' with Israel, senior official says
items.standfirst: Hamas has agreed to a ceasefire-hostage deal with Israel, according to a senior official.
items.content: Hamas has agreed to a ceasefire-hostage deal with Israel, according to a senior official.

items.title: Hamas agrees to latest Gaza ceasefire proposal
items.standfirst: Palestinian group Hamas on Monday agreed to a new proposal from mediators to end the nearly two-year-long war in the Gaza Strip, a Hamas source told AFP. The plan reportedly involves a 60-day ceasefire "during which 10 Israeli hostages would be released alive, along with a number of bodies", said a source from Islamic Jihad.

items.title: Flight attendant union leaders ‘ready to go to jail’ as Air Canada strike outlawed
items.standfirst: Arbitrator orders 10,000 striking staff back to work after government intervenes – unconstitutionally union saysUnion leaders representing 10,000 striking flight attendants have said they would be willing to go to jail rather than comply with an order to return to work, as Canada’s federal government seeks to end a bitter contract dispute that has halted hundreds of summer flights and stranded travellers around the world.Speaking to reporters on Monday, the national president of the Canadian Union of Public Employees said members would remain on the picket lines as part of a work stoppage that has halted Air Canada’s national and international operations during its busiest season. Continue reading...
items.content: Arbitrator orders 10,000 striking staff back to work after government intervenes – unconstitutionally union saysUnion leaders representing 10,000 striking flight attendants have said they would be willing to go to jail rather than comply with an order to return to work, as Canada’s federal government seeks to end a bitter contract dispute that has halted hundreds of summer flights and stranded travellers around the world.Speaking to reporters on Monday, the national president of the Canadian Union of Public Employees said members would remain on the picket lines as part of a work stoppage that has halted Air Canada’s national and international operations during its busiest season. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump is promising a US manufacturing renaissance. Many experts are dubious
items.standfirst: Economists doubt US duties will bring about a resurgence of US factory jobs, notably due to Trump’s erratic tariff rolloutDonald Trump’s hugely disruptive trade war is setting the stage for a manufacturing renaissance in the US, administration officials say. Outside the White House, many economists are skeptical.Global trade experts point to many reasons they believe the president’s tariffs will fail to bring about a major resurgence of manufacturing, among them: Trump’s erratic, constantly changing policies, his unfocused, across-the-board tariffs, and his replacing Joe Biden’s carrot-and-stick approach to brandish sticks at the world. Continue reading...
items.content: Economists doubt US duties will bring about a resurgence of US factory jobs, notably due to Trump’s erratic tariff rolloutDonald Trump’s hugely disruptive trade war is setting the stage for a manufacturing renaissance in the US, administration officials say. Continue reading...

clusters.ai_summary:

• Trump's policies are seen as erratic.
• The trade war is setting the stage for change.
